Award.AwardTitle: Partial Differential Equations in Conservation Laws and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is devoted to a mathematical study of some nonlinear partial differential equations in multi-dimensional conservation laws and related applications. In particular, the study focuses on the following topics from the theory of inviscid and viscous compressible flows and related applications: (a) Mixed-type PDE problems for transonic flows past an obstacle. (b) Mixed-type PDE problems for isometric embedding. (c) Existence and regularity of global solutions to the compressible multi-dimensional Navier-Stokes equations. (d) Global solutions to the viscous flows of related applications in liquid crystals. The goals of the research are: (a) To develop novel analytic methods and efficient techniques for solving some important problems in multi-dimensional inviscid and viscous conservation laws and applications. (b) To explore the qualitative behavior of flow motion. (c) To establish new connections of the isometric embedding problem with elastodynamics. (d) To gain insights into other multi-dimensional problems of conservation laws and emerging applications.

The aim of this research program is to develop new methods of analysis and techniques for studying some nonlinear partial differential equations governing the motion of compressible fluid flows and related applications. Compressible fluids such as gases are important in nature. Their study is crucial for understanding aerodynamics, atmospheric science, astrophysics, plasma physics, biology, elastodynamics, etc. While the one-dimensional problems are rather well understood, the general theory for the multi-dimensional case is mathematically underdeveloped. The project will advance the mathematical understanding of the multi-dimensional equations of compressible flows and related problems in emerging applications, and will provide education and training to students in this important field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the project period the following problems were studied, novel analytic methods and efficient techniques were developed, and new and significant results were obtained:

(1) For the Gauss-Codazzi equations of isometric immersion of surfaces,  global weak solutions were obtained by two approaches: vanishing viscosity method and Lax-Friedrichs scheme, which yields the global existence of C^{1,1} isometric immersion of two-dimensional manifolds including catenoid and helicoid types of and more general surfaces; and global existence of smooth solution was proved under an integrability condition, which yields a global smooth isometric immersion of surface in the three-dimensional Euclidean space even if the Gauss curvature decays very slowly at infinity. 

(2) A new proof was provided for the local  existence of smooth isometric embedding of a smooth 3-dimensional Riemannian manifold with nonzero Riemannian curvature tensor into 6-dimensional Euclidean space,  using the strong symmetric positivity for nonlinear, first-order PDE systems that do not fall under one of the standard types (elliptic, hyperbolic, and parabolic).

(3) New connections were developed for fluids, elasticity, geometry, and the existence of wrinkled solutions in two spatial dimensions. The results demonstrated that the continuum mechanical equations can be mapped into a corresponding geometric framework with the direct application of the theory of isometric embeddings and the Gauss-Codazzi equations through examples for the Euler equations for fluids and the Euler-Lagrange equations for elastic solids. These results show that the geometric theory provides an avenue for addressing the admissibility criteria for nonlinear conservation laws in continuum mechanics.  Also a theory for the evolution of a metric driven by the equations of three-dimensional continuum mechanics  was developed. The theory was applied to the incompressible Euler and Navier-Stokes equations. One practical outcome of the theory is a computation of critical profile initial data for what may be interpreted as the onset of turbulence for the classical incompressible Navier-Stokes equations. 

(4) The stability of compressible vortex sheets for the two-dimensional elastic flows was studied. A necessary and sufficient condition was obtained for the linear stability of the rectilinear vortex sheets. A new feature for elastic flow is found. As a result, the Kreiss symmetrization cannot be applied directly. Instead,  an upper triangularization of the system was performed to separate only the outgoing modes at all points in the frequency space. This new approach avoids the lengthy computation and estimates for the outgoing modes when Kreiss symmetrization is applied. This method can also be applied to the Euler flows and MHD flows. The linear stability of vortex sheets for the two-phase flows was also obtained. 

(5) The stochastic partial differential equations of fluid dynamics were studied. For the three-dimensional incompressible magnetohydrodynamic equations with multiplicative noise, the global existence of strong solutions in probability was established. For the three-dimensional stochastic compressible Navier-Stokes equations, the global martingale solution was constructed.

(6) The compressible flow of liquid crystals was studied with the following results: global existence of weak solution, large-time behavior, incompressible limit, and global existence of weak solution for a coupled compressible Navier-Stokes and Q-tensor system. For active hydrodynamics in biophysics, the hydrodynamics of active liquid crystals  was studied in the Beris-Edwards hydrodynamic framework with  Q-tensors, and the existence of global weak solutions in both the incompressible and compressible cases was established. 

(7) The fluid-particle flows were studied, and the following results were obtained: the global well-posedness of strong solution in the three-dimensional whole space, and the existence of global weak soltuions to an initial-boundary value problem for the inhomogeneous incompressible flows coupled with the Vlasov equation in a three-dimensional bounded domain. 

The methods and ideas developed in the project can be applied to study other problems in related areas. The mathematical issues addressed in the project are fundamental for the understanding of the dynamics of compressible flows and applications.  The research of the project (a) yielded new methods of analysis and efficient techniques for solving some important problems in multi-dimensional inviscid and viscous conservation laws and applications; (b) provided more insight into the qualitative behavior of flow motion; (c) established new connections of the isometric embedding problem in geometry with fluid dynamics and elastodynamics;  and (d) likely sheded light and provided important clue of new methods on other multi-dimensional problems of conservation laws and emerging applications. The research provided new understanding of the mathematics of fluids and gases critical for fluid dynamics, gas dynamics, active hydrodynamics in biology and biophysics, liquid crystals, and elastodynamics. The project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas.  In particular, the project provided advanced training for graduate students and allowed their participation in the research of some outstanding problems, via supervising graduate students (including a female student) and organizing workshops and working seminars; and disseminated new research results via the principal investigator's website, publications, mini-courses, and talks in conferences.
